channel.title: Fudge Messaging JIRA
channel.description: An XML representation of a search request

item.title: [FRN-93] Use and write type hints as per java
item.description:
Map, List, Set hints should be written as per java
hints should allow non generic IDictionary/IList... deserialization
item.summary: Use and write type hints as per java

item.title: [FRN-92] Reading java serialized collections throws exception
item.description:
Fix for FRJ-81 and FRJ-115 has changed the wire format.
Deserializing maps lists... from java now results in
"Sub-message doesn't contain a map (bad field " + field + ")"
item.summary: Reading java serialized collections throws exception

item.title: [FRN-91] Number of fields per message limited to a short
item.description: Number of fields per message limited to a short, when the spec has no specific limitation. Change this to be an int.
item.summary: Number of fields per message limited to a short

comments.comment: .net equivalent to FRJ-110

item.title: [FRN-90] Encoding a float as a JSON field then decoding back again yields a double rather than a float.
item.description: This is annoying but not important. Not fixed because it's non-trivial to tell when a string is float-sized rather than double-sized, and there are issues around loss of precision (e.g. 3.75e+15f when converted to a double does not give 3.75e+15).
item.summary: Encoding a float as a JSON field then decoding back again yields a double rather than a float.

item.title: [FRN-89] JSON encoding - verify all string representations of types match the spec
item.summary: JSON encoding - verify all string representations of types match the spec

comments.comment: Small niggle that converting from a float field to a JSON field then decoding back gives a double. Raised FRN-90 for this.

item.title: [FRN-88] JSON encoding mapping JSON arrays to primitive arrays or repeated fields as appropriate
item.summary: JSON encoding mapping JSON arrays to primitive arrays or repeated fields as appropriate

item.title: [FRN-87] JSON encoding handling of envelope fields
item.summary: JSON encoding handling of envelope fields

item.title: [FRN-86] JSON encoding name/ordinal logic
item.summary: JSON encoding name/ordinal logic

comments.comment: In the .net implementation, I've separated the name vs ordinal settings into two separate ones - one for encoding and one for decoding - as they are not really the same thing.

item.title: [FRN-85] FudgeMsgStreamReader should work on any IFudgeFieldContainer, not just FudgeMsg.
item.summary: FudgeMsgStreamReader should work on any IFudgeFieldContainer, not just FudgeMsg.

item.title: [FRN-84] FudgeSerializer should allow deserialisation of messages that don't necessarily contain the type
item.description: At the moment, you cannot take a simple message (e.g. one not generated by serialising an object) and deserialise it into an object, as there is no way of indicating what type you are expecting in FudgeSerializer.Deserialize().
item.summary: FudgeSerializer should allow deserialisation of messages that don't necessarily contain the type

item.title: [FRN-83] Get an interop test working for DateTime
item.description: See http://github.com/FudgeMsg/Fudge-Java/blob/JSR-310/tests/interop/org/fudgemsg/FudgeInteropTest.java
item.summary: Get an interop test working for DateTime

item.title: [FRN-82] Add HasField (string name) and HasField(int ordinal) to IFudgeFieldContainer
item.summary: Add HasField (string name) and HasField(int ordinal) to IFudgeFieldContainer

item.title: [FRN-81] Do some performance analysis of where time is spent in serialisation
item.description: At the moment, serialisation through the framework (rather than manually constructing the messages) is on par with but not faster than .net serialisation. That's a bit disappointing, so need to figure out what's slowing it down.
item.summary: Do some performance analysis of where time is spent in serialisation

comments.comment:
Done a first round of tuning, based on a simple tick class. We're now 50% faster than .net for [Serializable] and 30% faster for [DataContract]. Ironically, marking a class as [DataContract] is also faster than just having a bean but I've not looked into why that might be yet. Test class is Fudge.Tests.Perf.SerializationComparison.

Bean: 33472/s
Immutable: 28975/s
[Serializable]: 47826/s
ISerializable: 26440/s
[DataContract]: 53037/s
FudgeSerializable: 34604/s
.net [Serializable]: 31264/s
.net ISerializable: 31963/s
.net [DataContract]: 39315/s

item.title: [FRN-80] Collections should be equivalent when serializing
item.description:
There should be no difference in serializing a List<X>, X[], ICollection<X> and so on.

See also http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/aa347850.aspx for how M$ approach this in WCF data contracts.
item.summary: Collections should be equivalent when serializing

item.title: [FRN-79] Use the DataContract name and namespace where specified
item.description: The [DataContract] attribute allows you to specify a name and a namespace (URI). Need to work out how these interact with Fudge type names.
item.summary: Use the DataContract name and namespace where specified

item.title: [FRN-78] Support [OnSerializing], [OnSerialized], [OnDeserializing] and [OnDeserialized] attributes from .net serialization framework.
item.summary: Support [OnSerializing], [OnSerialized], [OnDeserializing] and [OnDeserialized] attributes from .net serialization framework.

item.title: [FRN-77] Support [Serializable] and [NonSerialized] attributes from .net serialization framework
item.summary: Support [Serializable] and [NonSerialized] attributes from .net serialization framework

item.title: [FRN-76] Support the WCF DataContractAttribute and DataMemberAttribute for serialization
item.summary: Support the WCF DataContractAttribute and DataMemberAttribute for serialization

item.title: [FRN-75] Uri as a secondary type
item.summary: Uri as a secondary type

item.title: [FRN-74] Make sure Indicator can be deserialized to null for all (relevant) types.
item.summary: Make sure Indicator can be deserialized to null for all (relevant) types.

item.title: [FRN-73] Add support for IDeserializationCallback
item.summary: Add support for IDeserializationCallback

item.title: [FRN-72] Serializing list of value type crashes
item.description: CollectionSurrogateBase.CreateMethodDelegate requires T to be a reference type.
item.summary: Serializing list of value type crashes

comments.comment: The reason this was crashing was that there was a ": class" constraint on various methods, stemming back to FudgeDeserializationContext.FromField<T>. I'm not sure why I put this constraint in in the first place, but removing it seems to cause no damange and fixes the problem.

item.title: [FRN-71] Cycles within immutable objects when deserializing
item.description:
Immutable object A contains mutable object B which refers back to A. At the moment this will fail in deserialization because at the point where inner A is referenced it has not been constructed.

In .net it us actually possible to construct an object in an uninitialized state and then later call the constructor, enabling us to register it with the deserializer before attempting to deserialize B.
item.summary: Cycles within immutable objects when deserializing

item.title: [FRN-70] Remove factories for surrogates now they don't need any state
item.summary: Remove factories for surrogates now they don't need any state

item.title: [FRN-69] Make .net JSON reader/writer conform to Fudge spec
item.description: http://www.fudgemsg.org/display/FDG/JSON+Fudge+Messages
item.summary: Make .net JSON reader/writer conform to Fudge spec

item.title: [FRN-68] Encoding Fudge streams as JSON messages
item.summary: Encoding Fudge streams as JSON messages

item.title: [FRN-67] In FudgeInterOpTest, there is a field in the message which is a byte[100000] but is misnamed.
item.description: This needs fixing simultaneously in Java and C#
item.summary: In FudgeInterOpTest, there is a field in the message which is a byte[100000] but is misnamed.

item.title: [FRN-65] FudgeSerializationContext uses GetHashCode and Equals on objects to determine identity
item.description:
This is potentially slow (if the object's GetHashCode is slow), and also could result it two objects which are distinct but equal being serialized as the same object in the graph.

Need to find some way of getting an object's real identity, but not sure this is possible in .net.
item.summary: FudgeSerializationContext uses GetHashCode and Equals on objects to determine identity

comments.comment: Should switch to using ObjectIDGenerator, which was designed for exactly this.

item.title: [FRN-64] Write a FastInvoke replacement for the DynamicInvoke currently used in FudgeLinqProvider to improve performance.
item.summary: Write a FastInvoke replacement for the DynamicInvoke currently used in FudgeLinqProvider to improve performance.

comments.comment: Duplicate of FRN-4

item.title: [FRN-63] Handle fields without names, and also ordinals in XML streaming
item.summary: Handle fields without names, and also ordinals in XML streaming

item.title: [FRN-62] Sort out use of envelopes in stream readers/writers, then get rid of FudgeStreamParser
item.summary: Sort out use of envelopes in stream readers/writers, then get rid of FudgeStreamParser

item.title: [FRN-61] Move FudgeStreamPipe into Util namespace
item.summary: Move FudgeStreamPipe into Util namespace

item.title: [FRN-60] Implement latest encoding standard
item.summary: Implement latest encoding standard

item.title: [FRN-59] Tidy up use of FudgeRuntimeException
item.summary: Tidy up use of FudgeRuntimeException

item.title: [FRN-58] Decimal type
item.summary: Decimal type

item.title: [FRN-57] Support rich constructor immutable objects
item.description: Reflection-based handling of immutable classes where all props are passed to constructor
item.summary: Support rich constructor immutable objects

item.title: [FRN-56] Implement new serialization standard
item.summary: Implement new serialization standard

item.title: [FRN-55] Add thread safety comments in xmldoc
item.description:
Include in the comment for each concrete class whether an instance is safe to share between threads or not. If it's an abstract class, include any notes relevant to the writer of a sub-class for them to determine their sub-classes thread safety.

In the cases of non-shareable, explain why or give guidance on how to use it safely.
item.summary: Add thread safety comments in xmldoc

item.title: [FRN-54] Remove TODO comments from code
item.description: Any outstanding TODOs to be identified and either acted on, deleted, or filed in JIRA as a proper task.
item.summary: Remove TODO comments from code

comments.comment: Handled all my TODOs. Not tackled Andrew's yet.

item.title: [FRN-53] Close any issues that have been merged back into the master
item.description: As discussed (and now documented on the Wiki - http://wiki.fudgemsg.org/display/FDG/Use+of+Jira+and+Git), close any of the tasks that are currently marked as resolved but have been merged successfully into the master branch.
item.summary: Close any issues that have been merged back into the master

item.summary: Add context property to control default inlining behaviour

comments.comment: This is no longer relevant with the new standard for serialization.

item.summary: Check for cycles when in-lining objects

item.description:
Attribute on class should override default behaviour for whether the class is inlined or referenced.
Attribute on a property should override behaviour specified by property type.

item.summary: Switch list serialization to be as a sub-message rather than a repeating field.

item.summary: Add base types when outputting type name

comments.comment: And uses the first recognised type when deserialising.

item.title: [FRN-42] Add namespace documentation and clean up other XML comments
item.summary: Add namespace documentation and clean up other XML comments

item.title: [FRN-41] Remove need to have assembly name in type field
item.summary: Remove need to have assembly name in type field

item.title: [FRN-40] Provide type name mapping (e.g. .net to Java package names)
item.summary: Provide type name mapping (e.g. .net to Java package names)

item.summary: Allow surrogate to be specified through attribute on class

item.summary: Support toFudgeMsg/fromFudgeMsg convention

item.summary: Get consistency with Java implementation

item.title: [FRN-36] Support FudgeFieldOrdinal on properties
item.summary: Support FudgeFieldOrdinal on properties

item.title: [FRN-35] Field name conventions (e.g. camelCase) for serialization
item.description: Should support through attribute on type, and also as a context property
item.summary: Field name conventions (e.g. camelCase) for serialization

comments.comment: Now supports FieldNameConvention attribute on type and a matching context property. Currently supports identity, upper, lower, PascalCase and camelCase.

item.title: [FRN-34] Support FudgeFieldName and FudgeTransient attributes on properties
item.summary: Support FudgeFieldName and FudgeTransient attributes on properties

item.title: [FRN-33] Serialization
item.description: Serialization framework for serializing .net objects to and from Fudge streams
item.summary: Serialization

item.title: [FRN-32] Allow behaviour of automatic mapping from FudgeDateTime to DateTime to be configured in the context.
item.description: Allow the default logic for conversion from FudgeDateTime to DateTime when it has an offset to be configurable using a ContextProperty. E.g. treat unknown as UTC, map everything to UTC, map everything to local, ignore all timezone info, map to DateTimeKind.Local if the offset matches, etc.
item.summary: Allow behaviour of automatic mapping from FudgeDateTime to DateTime to be configured in the context.

item.title: [FRN-31] Further features in FudgeDateTime etc. classes
item.description:
TODO:

  • Full implementation of IComparable<>
  • Conversion of FudgeDate to and from Julian dates
  • Date and time arithmetic
  • Mapping between FudgeTime and TimeSpan
item.summary: Further features in FudgeDateTime etc. classes

item.title: [FRN-30] New DateTime encoding
item.description: New encoding with the three types - Date, Time and DateTime
item.summary: New DateTime encoding

comments.comment: Checked in current implementation and pushed to master. Will raise new JIRAs for further work.

item.title: [FRN-29] Make sure all readers behave properly if stream ends prematurely or if underlying socket is closed
item.summary: Make sure all readers behave properly if stream ends prematurely or if underlying socket is closed

item.title: [FRN-28] Create sample solution sending messages across a socket
item.summary: Create sample solution sending messages across a socket

item.title: [FRN-27] Improve performance of FudgeContext construction
item.description: At the moment, constructing a FudgeContext takes around 13 microseconds (on my machine), which is nontrivial compared to other operations (for example streaming out a simple message to binary only takes 7 microseconds once the context exists). Nearly all this time is in constructing the FudgeTypeDictionary so that needs some attention.
item.summary: Improve performance of FudgeContext construction

comments.comment: Or is this not important as we expect people to construct one context and then use it for everything?

Are you constructing a new FudgeTypeDictionary for each FudgeContext? We've got a static instance that's pre-allocated on classloading that's used for cases where they don't specify their own FudgeTypeDictionary, and that seems to work pretty well.

I DO however think that in general, most apps will have extremely few numbers of FudgeContexts as it's a reasonably significant setup with all the control parameters we're working on (like taxonomy resolvers and the like).

item.title: [FRN-26] Support multiple messages in a binary stream
item.description: At the moment the FudgeEncodedStreamReader can only read one message from a stream. It should be able to continue reading messages as long as there is more data.
item.summary: Support multiple messages in a binary stream

comments.comment: We've already got some code which does this, but it fails on the final bit where the stream is closed. I think this is somewhat related though which is why I've linked the two issues.

The thing that I've not figured out yet is what the behaviour of hasNext on a streamreader should be when you're at the end of one message but not yet started the next. The simplest thing to code would be for it to block until either the stream is closed or it receives more data, but this feels a bit wrong for the usual hasNext/moveNext pattern. However, this is what my XML and JSON readers will do already because of the way the underlying .net reader classes it uses work so if the Java implementation works similarly then we should go with that.

item.title: [FRN-25] Improve performance of FudgeEncodedStreamWriter
item.description:
The FudgeEncodedStreamWriter currently builds up a hierarchy of FudgeMsgs which it only encodes to binary when it has the full tree because it has to calculate the size of each submessage before it writes it.

Proposal is to write straight to a MemoryStream as fields come in, but leave placeholders for the submessage sizes that can be filled in as each submessage is completed (as we can seek around the MemoryStream). This will reduce the memory footprint of the data before it is written to the output stream, but also hopefully be faster as we'll not be creating as many objects or doing as much processing.

The catch is that the number of bytes needed to store the size of a submessage depends on the size itself, so we'll have to initially use four bytes and then drop the unnecessary bytes as we output to the real stream, which will add some overhead.
item.summary: Improve performance of FudgeEncodedStreamWriter

comments.comment: Performance now more than doubled compared to old implementation.
Actually, ignoring the cost of creating the context it's seven times faster!

item.title: [FRN-24] Field should not require an empty context
item.description: Field only uses the context to derive the type for values. This doesn't actually need to be done until the field is added to a FudgeMsg, which will already have a context.
item.summary: Field should not require an empty context

item.title: [FRN-23] Move type conversion logic out of FudgeMsg into Context
item.summary: Move type conversion logic out of FudgeMsg into Context

item.title: [FRN-22] Allow FudgeMsgStreamWriter to signal when it has a new complete message
item.description: This would mean that you could have a thread listening on a socket, and as data is received it is unpacked, then when a complete FudgeMsg is ready and event is raised so it can be processed.
item.summary: Allow FudgeMsgStreamWriter to signal when it has a new complete message

comments.comment: FudgeMsgStreamWriter is the wrong place to do this - I've added an event to the FudgeStreamPipe instead.

item.title: [FRN-21] Streaming interfaces should easily support multiple messages in a single stream.
item.description:
It should be quite possible to send multiple messages down a single stream, but the interfaces as they currently stand don't really support that.

Proposal is to rename the "MessageEnvelope" element type to be "MessageStart" (as distinct from SubmessageFieldStart, and add an additional "MessageEnd". The IFudgeStreamWriter would then rename End() to be EndMessage() and have an additional StartMessage().

This would also simplify some of the existing logic in the readers and writers which have to deal with the open and close message tags (e.g. the outermost { and } in JSON).
item.summary: Streaming interfaces should easily support multiple messages in a single stream.

item.title: [FRN-20] Sort out XML comments for new streaming stuff
item.summary: Sort out XML comments for new streaming stuff

item.title: [FRN-19] Review the StreamDecoder/Encoder implementation
item.description:
This needs to be looked at in conjunction with the Java API. I'm leaning towards preferring classes like FudgeStreamReader, which can read & decode the individual Fudge elements that is then used by a FudgeMessageReader to read whole messages. This can then be built on to deliver Readers that can produce complex C# objects (i.e. specific to business logics / application data model) from an underlying Fudge transport.

Calling it a Reader rather than a Decrypt is a bit more in keeping with the spirit of the .NET framework as it is in turn being wrapped around a BinaryReader.

Same applies to the Encrypt/Writing side of things.
item.summary: Review the StreamDecoder/Encoder implementation

comments.comment: Have a look at my streaming branch before you start working on this.
The .NET streaming solution works well and is now in the main branch. The Java APIs have since moved on as part of FRJ-13. I'm closing this issue.

item.title: [FRN-18] Use of FudgeContext more consistant with Java API
item.description: The static type dictionary instance should not be needed, and a FudgeContext should be passed about instead of FudgeTypeDictionary objects as this has a dictionary and is also capable of creating new messages (which need a context).
item.summary: Use of FudgeContext more consistant with Java API

comments.comment: Definitely agree with passing the context rather than the type dictionary - this also fits with the work I was doing on context params, and was a sticking point for me continuing with the datetime implementation.

item.title: [FRN-17] Review FudgeContext implementation
item.description:
A version of toByteArray that takes a taxonomy too might be convenient
A Serialize that takes a FudgeMsgEnvelope instead of the FudgeMsg for better symmetry with Deserialize
A Deserialize that can process a fragment of data from within a byte array
item.summary: Review FudgeContext implementation

item.title: [FRN-16] Review Field.cs implementation
item.description: I'm not sure about the implementation of this class. I like the convenience, but not the static type resolver. I think we should look at putting a convenience method into FudgeContext instead, similar to NewMessage that uses the correct type resolver.
item.summary: Review Field.cs implementation

comments.comment: Yeah, the static type dictionary is ugly. I was trying to mimic the XElement style of construction which still allows for immutability (rather than doing builder-style .Add(blah).Add(blah) etc.), but I'm not sure we can really do that now the context is so critical.
OK - I've removed the static context in FRN-24, so see if you think this issue needs any more work.

item.title: [FRN-15] DateTime encoding support
item.description: Supporting datetime as a native Fudge encoding type. See wiki post at http://wiki.fudgemsg.org/display/FDG/DateTime+encoding.
item.summary: DateTime encoding support

item.title: [FRN-14] Create extensible method for adding properties to a context to control encoding behaviour
item.summary: Create extensible method for adding properties to a context to control encoding behaviour

item.title: [FRN-13] Tidy up XML comments and add namespace summaries
item.description: Following on from FRN-3, Sandcastle is throwing lots of warmnings due to missing comments. Need to use <inheritdoc/> lots and also add (in the Sandcastle project) summaries for each namespace.
item.summary: Tidy up XML comments and add namespace summaries

comments.comment: Namespaces and most of the main methods/classes are all XML commented.

item.title: [FRN-12] No Interop Test that covers 64-bit integers
item.description: Apparently the StandardFudgeMessages block that's used for interop testing doesn't actually include a message that includes a 64-bit integer, because all the values are downscaled to INT32. We need a separate interop test (so that we don't mess with any existing ones) that includes actual positive and negative 64-bit integers.
item.summary: No Interop Test that covers 64-bit integers

comments.comment: FRJ-26 and FRN-12 should be fixed at the same time.
See FRJ-26.

item.title: [FRN-11] Port FRJ-13 - streaming interface replacement for encoder/decoder
item.summary: Port FRJ-13 - streaming interface replacement for encoder/decoder

item.title: [FRN-10] Implement secondary types for Guid and IPAddress
item.description: Needs to wait for agreement that the current approach in .net is correct.
item.summary: Implement secondary types for Guid and IPAddress

comments.comment: Note that I've done a Guid implementation in my FRN-15 branch.
Having looked a bit more closely, I think the .NET approach is sensible. The pattern translates well into Java using inheritance from a SecondaryFieldType class.

item.title: [FRN-9] Objects should be streamed out as serialised, not put in parent message
item.description: The current implementation puts everything into one big message that is then sent out. If we can stream out objects as they are serialised then this will be more efficient (as IO can happen concurrently with serialisation).
item.summary: Objects should be streamed out as serialised, not put in parent message

comments.comment: I definitely agree with this. While the Java RI started out trying to do a streaming system, somewhere along the way that definitely got lost. I think the new encoding specification (with just an envelope and then a number of fields) is much more amenable to streaming.
This would also help with memory usage, since the FudgeMsg objects can be significantly bigger than the objects they represent, or even their encoded form

item.title: [FRN-8] Separate out the assembly version number and make build process automatically increment the last number.
item.description: Follow-on from FRN-7. We're doing major.minor.patch.build, so the automatic build script should generate the build number. This should be shared across the projects.
item.summary: Separate out the assembly version number and make build process automatically increment the last number.

item.title: [FRN-7] Set the assembly version and meta info
item.summary: Set the assembly version and meta info

item.title: [FRN-6] Write bridge for types that implement the standard .net ISerializable interface or use an ISerializationSurrogate
item.description: This isn't ideal performance-wise as you end up copying the values twice, but it provides an easy entry point for people that have already written serialisation code.
item.summary: Write bridge for types that implement the standard .net ISerializable interface or use an ISerializationSurrogate

comments.comment:
Whilst serialisation should be OK, I'm not sure deserialization is possible - objects implementing ISerializable are supposed to have a constructor taking a SerializationInfo which is used for deserialization, and this assumes that all the sub-objects have been deserialized. Because we represent many things as a submsg, the framework can't tell whether it's a sub-object or not, so cannot automatically deserialize sub-objects.

We could just put the FudgeMsg as the object in the SerializationInfo and let the class deal with it, but this makes the object have to understand Fudge which defeats the purpose.

ISerializable is a PITA. When deserializing, the obvious approach is to call SerializationInfo.GetString(), etc. to pull out each field by name. Only problem is that if the field is missing (which is the way we serialize nulls in Fudge) then SerializationInfo will throw an exception rather than returning null, and there's no way of overriding this behaviour.

Approach I'm going to take is when using ISerializable, nulls are serialized to Indicator rather than being omitted. Need to think about the implicatons especially cross-language.

item.title: [FRN-5] Port FRJ-11: Need a .GetMessage() method similar to all the other shortcut field methods.
item.summary: Port FRJ-11: Need a .GetMessage() method similar to all the other shortcut field methods.

item.title: [FRN-4] Implement a FastInvoke invoker rather than using DynamicInvoke to execute Linq expressions
item.description: Have a look at http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/magazine/cc163759.aspx#S3 - this is why IQToolkit has QueryCompiler.CompiledQuery doing the FastInvoke thing.
item.summary: Implement a FastInvoke invoker rather than using DynamicInvoke to execute Linq expressions

item.title: [FRN-3] Get a documentation build working
item.description:
Suggest using the Sandcastle help file builder - see http://www.ewoodruff.us/shfbdocs/Index.aspx?topic=html/8c0c97d0-c968-4c15-9fe9-e8f3a443c50a.htm

(note that NDoc is pretty-much dead now)
item.summary: Get a documentation build working

comments.comment: Note that the SandCastle help file builder relies on a service pack for VS2008, so isn't usable with VC# Express.
Got a basic htmlhelp1 (i.e. chm) version working. Need to tidy up the comments - lots missing including namespace overviews.

item.title: [FRN-2] Use true UTF-8 encoding for Strings
item.description:
Right now Fudge is using Modified UTF-8. We should convert to true UTF-8.

This is not going into 0.1 because it will only impact the way certain odd characters (like Unicode 0x0) get encoded.
item.summary: Use true UTF-8 encoding for Strings

comments.comment: This is a trivial change to FudgeBinaryReader/Writer, but needs to be done at the same time as FRJ-9 to keep the interop tests working.

You'd think it would be a trivial change for the Java side as well, but it isn't due to the way that Sun decided to implement encoding systems. I've deferred doing that thus far specifically due to the possible speed overhead.

Not quite as simple as I thought, but done now. Interop tests still pass.

Available in http://github.com/t0rx/Fudge-CSharp/tree/FNR-2_UTF8Encoding

item.title: [FRN-1] Linq: Introduce caching so that it doesn't Reflection.Emit every time you run a query
item.description:
At the moment, each time a query is executed, the expression tree is manipulated into a couple of lambdas that are then compiled and executed. The compilation is actually emitting IL, which is a slow process.

In the IQToolkit there is a QueryCache which helps with this, but as we manipulate the tree then what we should do is cache the two final lambdas against the original expression tree so that we can skip the manipulation also.
item.summary: Linq: Introduce caching so that it doesn't Reflection.Emit every time you run a query

comments.comment: Added caching and a couple of other improvements. There's still some more mileage in that it currently uses Delegate.DynamicInvoke - see http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/magazine/cc163759.aspx#S3
